TITLE: Freezing BatchNorm Statistics During Training in Python
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use a callback to freeze BatchNorm statistics when freezing layers during training. It defines a 'put_in_eval_mode' function that sets frozen layers to evaluation mode to prevent BatchNorm values from changing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/usage/callbacks.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from ultralytics import YOLO


# Add a callback to put the frozen layers in eval mode to prevent BN values from changing
def put_in_eval_mode(trainer):
    n_layers = trainer.args.freeze
    if not isinstance(n_layers, int):
        return

    for i, (name, module) in enumerate(trainer.model.named_modules()):
        if name.endswith("bn") and int(name.split(".")[1]) < n_layers:
            module.eval()
            module.track_running_stats = False


model = YOLO("yolo11n.pt")
model.add_callback("on_train_epoch_start", put_in_eval_mode)
model.train(data="coco.yaml", epochs=10)
```

TITLE: Using MobileSAM with Box Prompts in Python

```
from ultralytics import SAM

# Load the model
model = SAM("mobile_sam.pt")

# Predict a segment based on a single point prompt
model.predict("ultralytics/assets/zidane.jpg", points=[900, 370], labels=[1])

# Predict multiple segments based on multiple points prompt
model.predict("ultralytics/assets/zidane.jpg", points=[[400, 370], [900, 370]], labels=[1, 1])

# Predict a segment based on multiple points prompt per object
model.predict("ultralytics/assets/zidane.jpg", points=[[[400, 370], [900, 370]]], labels=[[1, 1]])

# Predict a segment using both positive and negative prompts.
model.predict("ultralytics/assets/zidane.jpg", points=[[[400, 370], [900, 370]]], labels=[[1, 0]])
```

TITLE: Profiling and Comparing Models in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to profile various segmentation models including SAM, FastSAM, and YOLO, comparing their size and speed. It assumes access to the model files and 'ultralytics' library, running tests on specified assets to obtain performance metrics.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/models/sam-2.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from ultralytics import ASSETS, SAM, YOLO, FastSAM

# Profile SAM2-t, SAM2-b, SAM-b, MobileSAM
for file in ["sam_b.pt", "sam2_b.pt", "sam2_t.pt", "mobile_sam.pt"]:
    model = SAM(file)
    model.info()
    model(ASSETS)

# Profile FastSAM-s
model = FastSAM("FastSAM-s.pt")
model.info()
model(ASSETS)

# Profile YOLO models
for file_name in ["yolov8n-seg.pt", "yolo11n-seg.pt"]:
    model = YOLO(file_name)
    model.info()
    model(ASSETS)
```

TITLE: Google-Style Python Docstring Example
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the proper format for Google-style docstrings in Python functions, including argument types, return values, and examples.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/help/contributing.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def example_function(arg1, arg2=4):
    """
    Example function demonstrating Google-style docstrings.

    Args:
        arg1 (int): The first argument.
        arg2 (int): The second argument, with a default value of 4.

    Returns:
        (bool): True if successful, False otherwise.

    Examples:
        >>> result = example_function(1, 2)  # returns False
    """
    if arg1 == arg2:
        return True
    return False
```

TITLE: Cropping Images Using Bounding Box Coordinates in Python
DESCRIPTION: Extracts bounding box coordinates from a detection result, converts them to integers, and crops the isolated image to the object region. This technique is useful for obtaining only the part of the image containing the detected object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/guides/isolating-segmentation-objects.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# (1) Bounding box coordinates
x1, y1, x2, y2 = c.boxes.xyxy.cpu().numpy().squeeze().astype(np.int32)
# Crop image to object region
iso_crop = isolated[y1:y2, x1:x2]

TITLE: Optimizing and Zipping Dataset with Ultralytics Utils
DESCRIPTION: Python script demonstrating how to optimize images in a dataset using compression and create a zip archive using Ultralytics utility functions. The script processes all JPG images recursively and creates a compressed dataset archive.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/datasets/index.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pathlib import Path

from ultralytics.data.utils import compress_one_image
from ultralytics.utils.downloads import zip_directory

# Define dataset directory
path = Path("path/to/dataset")

# Optimize images in dataset (optional)
for f in path.rglob("*.jpg"):
    compress_one_image(f)

# Zip dataset into 'path/to/dataset.zip'
zip_directory(path)
```

TITLE: Running YOLO Inference on a PyTorch Tensor in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to perform YOLO inference using a PyTorch tensor as input. It requires importing `torch` and `YOLO`. A random PyTorch tensor is created with the expected BCHW format (Batch, Channels, Height, Width), RGB channel order, and float32 data type (values normalized between 0.0 and 1.0). This tensor is passed to the loaded YOLO model for inference, returning a list of Results objects.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/modes/predict.md#2025-04-22_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import torch

from ultralytics import YOLO

# Load a pretrained YOLO11n model
model = YOLO("yolo11n.pt")

# Create a random torch tensor of BCHW shape (1, 3, 640, 640) with values in range [0, 1] and type float32
source = torch.rand(1, 3, 640, 640, dtype=torch.float32)

# Run inference on the source
results = model(source)  # list of Results objects
```

TITLE: Complete YOLO Terminal Visualization Example
DESCRIPTION: Full implementation combining all steps to display YOLO inference results in terminal
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/guides/view-results-in-terminal.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import io

import cv2
from sixel import SixelWriter

from ultralytics import YOLO

# Load a model
model = YOLO("yolo11n.pt")

# Run inference on an image
results = model.predict(source="ultralytics/assets/bus.jpg")

# Plot inference results
plot = results[0].plot()

# Results image as bytes
im_bytes = cv2.imencode(
    ".png",
    plot,
)[1].tobytes()

mem_file = io.BytesIO(im_bytes)
w = SixelWriter()
w.draw(mem_file)
```

DESCRIPTION: Commands for building the MNN library with OpenCV integration and image codecs enabled
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/examples/YOLOv8-MNN-CPP/README.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
mkdir build && cd build

cmake -DMNN_BUILD_OPENCV=ON -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF -DMNN_IMGCODECS=ON ..

make -j$(nproc)
```

TITLE: CLA Signing Comment Text
DESCRIPTION: The exact text needed to sign the Contributor License Agreement in a pull request comment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/help/contributing.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
I have read the CLA Document and I sign the CLA
```

TITLE: Initializing ClearML Configuration
DESCRIPTION: This command initializes the ClearML configuration by connecting the SDK to the server. It requires user interaction to input credentials.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/yolov5/tutorials/clearml_logging_integration.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
clearml-init
```

TITLE: Finding Free Network Port in Python
DESCRIPTION: Function to find a free network port for distributed training. It uses socket programming to identify an available port.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/reference/utils/dist.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
ultralytics.utils.dist.find_free_network_port
```

TITLE: Adjusting Batch Logging Interval in Comet ML
DESCRIPTION: Modifies the batch logging interval for Comet ML during YOLO11 training using an environment variable.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/integrations/comet.md#2025-04-22_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import os

os.environ["COMET_EVAL_BATCH_LOGGING_INTERVAL"] = "4"
```

TITLE: Revoking Docker Display Access
DESCRIPTION: Command to revoke Docker's access to the local display server after finishing GUI operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/guides/docker-quickstart.md#2025-04-22_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
xhost -local:docker
```

TITLE: Resuming an Interrupted YOLO Training Session in Bash
DESCRIPTION: Command to resume a previously interrupted YOLO training session using the last saved checkpoint.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/usage/cli.md#2025-04-22_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
yolo detect train resume model=last.pt
```

TITLE: Initializing Embeddings Table
DESCRIPTION: Creates an Explorer instance with VOC dataset and builds embeddings table for similarity search
SOURCE: https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/blob/main/docs/en/datasets/explorer/explorer.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
exp = Explorer("VOC.yaml", model="yolo11n.pt")
exp.create_embeddings_table()
```
